articles.headline: In U.S. Data, a Baffling Contradiction
articles.snippet: The government says that the first quarter of 2014 was the worst for the economy since 2009, but the best in hiring in over six years. How can both reports be right?
articles.abstract: The government says that the first quarter of 2014 was the worst for the economy since 2009, but the best in hiring in over six years. How can both reports be right?
articles.lead_paragraph: The first quarter of this year was the worst for the United States economy since the depths of the Great Recession in early 2009.

articles.headline: Despite a Pledge by Samsung, Child Labor Proves Resilient
articles.snippet: The presence of at least three under-age workers at a Shinyang Electronics factory casts a cloud over the labor practices of Samsung and its suppliers.
articles.abstract: The presence of at least three under-age workers at a Shinyang Electronics factory casts a cloud over the labor practices of Samsung and its suppliers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DONGGUAN, China — After work, the three teenage girls giggle and pull at one another’s hair. But when questioned, they admit their common secret: They use false papers to work illegally here at the factory that makes mobile phone components for one of the world’s biggest brands, Samsung.

articles.headline: Questcor Reveals Adverse Events Data for Acthar for First Time
articles.snippet: The drug manufacturer, recipient of a $5.6 billion takeover bid, disclosed that almost 5 percent of prescriptions generated reports of ill effects.
articles.abstract: The drug manufacturer, recipient of a $5.6 billion takeover bid, disclosed that almost 5 percent of prescriptions generated reports of ill effects.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Questcor Pharmaceuticals has highlighted the potential benefits of Acthar, its immune-system drug, while saying little about its ill effects.

articles.headline: Shadowy Rebel Wields Iron Fist in Ukraine Fight
articles.snippet: Once marked as a dead man, Igor Strelkov made his first public appearance in Donetsk in a move to assert authority over fractious separatist militias.
articles.abstract: Once marked as a dead man, Igor Strelkov made his first public appearance in Donetsk in a move to assert authority over fractious separatist militias.
articles.lead_paragraph: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — Late one afternoon last month, as separatist militia fighters and Ukrainian forces exchanged fire, a small-time thief by the name of Aleksei B. Pichko left his home on the southern edge of Slovyansk and headed for an abandoned residence at 17 Sadovaya Street. He had been drinking, and wanted to “see what could be stolen from there,” according to documents recovered at the rebel headquarters after their retreat over the weekend.

articles.headline: Natural Gas Pipeline Plan Creates Rift in Massachusetts
articles.snippet: Property owners are caught between the need to cooperate with increasing the energy supply and the desire to protect their land.
articles.abstract: Property owners are caught between the need to cooperate with increasing the energy supply and the desire to protect their land.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTHFIELD, Mass. — Standing on a dirt road outside his aging barn, Walter Jaworski, a former veterinarian turned cattle rancher in this rural part of north-central Massachusetts, points south across his 200 acres of forest and pasture to a nearby tree line. If things don’t go his way, he says, that’s about where a new natural gas pipeline will slice through his land on a 180-mile journey from central New York to a transmission hub north of Boston.

articles.headline: Killing of Palestinian Youth Puts an Israeli Focus on Extremism
articles.snippet: Some are observing a generational shift as Jewish youth in Israel express a distinct anti-Arab attitude that was not learned in the home.
articles.abstract: Some are observing a generational shift as Jewish youth in Israel express a distinct anti-Arab attitude that was not learned in the home.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Even as the Israeli public offers strong support for airstrikes on Hamas fighters and their weapons stocks in Gaza, there is a good deal of reflection over the coldblooded killing of a Palestinian teenager that helped lead to the latest increase in violence.

articles.headline: A Provocateur’s Book on Hillary Clinton Overtakes Her Memoir in Sales
articles.snippet: Edward Klein’s “Blood Feud: The Clintons vs. the Obamas,” a 320-page unauthorized and barely sourced account, has toppled “Hard Choices” from its spot on the best-seller list.
articles.abstract: Edward Klein’s “Blood Feud: The Clintons vs. the Obamas,” a 320-page unauthorized and barely sourced account, has toppled “Hard Choices” from its spot on the best-seller list.
articles.lead_paragraph: Of all the headaches of her current book tour — the declining sales, the constant travel, the interviews that generated unkind headlines about her family’s wealth — this one may sting Hillary Rodham Clinton the most: Her memoir, “Hard Choices,” has just been toppled from its spot on the best-seller list by a sensational Clinton account by her longtime antagonist Edward Klein.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Alexandra Alter

articles.headline: Reynolds in Talks to Acquire Lorillard in Merger of Tobacco Rivals
articles.snippet: Confronting a shrinking market of smokers, a deal would unite some of the best-selling brands in cigarettes, including Camel and Newport.
articles.abstract: Confronting a shrinking market of smokers, a deal would unite some of the best-selling brands in cigarettes, including Camel and Newport.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:17 p.m. | Hoping to combat a decades-long slump in smoking, two of the biggest American tobacco companies said on Friday that they were in talks to merge and create a $56 billion cigarette colossus.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Chad Bray

articles.headline: Kerry Pushes for Solution to Afghanistan Election Crisis
articles.snippet: Secretary of State John Kerry visited Afghanistan in an effort to resolve an impasse between Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani, who each claim to have won the presidency.
articles.abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry visited Afghanistan in an effort to resolve an impasse between Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani, who each claim to have won the presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Obama administration had hoped that after years of frustration with President Hamid Karzai, a successful election in Afghanistan would finally produce a leader who could stabilize the country while working with the United States to allow an orderly withdrawal of American troops and end its longest war.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Carlotta Gall

articles.headline: Saving for Bucket List That’s Likely to Evolve in Years Before Retirement
articles.snippet: Research shows that what people think now that they will want to do in retirement will probably change. The right planning can prepare for that shift.
articles.abstract: Research shows that what people think now that they will want to do in retirement will probably change. The right planning can prepare for that shift.
articles.lead_paragraph: When most of us imagine retirement, our minds wander to what we’ll get to do then that we don’t have enough time for now. If we’re lucky, we can push the uncertainty of our investment performance and future health out of our minds and picture all the fun we’ll have. That’s what will make the decades of saving worthwhile, after all.
